message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the elevated D-dimer level suggested pulmonary embolism. Localized rales will be the most likely finding as they indicate the presence of fluid in the lungs and can be heard on auscultation. Wheezing is associated with asthma, systolic murmurs are usually heart-related, and pleural friction rubs are associated with pleurisy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with difficulty in breathing and an elevated D-dimer level, which suggests a pulmonary embolism. Localized rales would be the most likely sign observed during the physical examination of this patient’s chest in the case of pulmonary embolism. Bilateral wheezing suggests asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). A systolic murmur at left sternal border would suggest aortic stenosis. Pleural friction rub suggests pleuritis or inflammation of the pleura.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and elevated D-dimer level suggest pulmonary embolism. Localized rales are the most likely finding on physical examination as they indicate fluid in the lungs, which can be caused by a pulmonary embolism. Bilateral wheezing is more indicative of asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, while a systolic murmur at the left sternal border and pleural friction rub are more indicative of cardiovascular or pleural diseases, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and elevated D-dimer level suggest pulmonary embolism, which can be confirmed by the CT scan. Among the options, localized rales is the most likely sign to be observed during physical examination of the chest in this case, as it indicates lung tissue affected by the embolism. Bilateral wheezing can suggest asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, but not pulmonary embolism. Systolic murmur at the left sternal border and pleural friction rub are not typical of pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient showed symptoms of pulmonary embolism and the physical examination can reveal pulmonary findings. Localized rales, or crackles, can indicate fluid accumulation in the lungs which can be caused by pulmonary embolism. Bilateral wheezing suggests obstructive lung disease, systolic murmur suggests cardiac pathology, and pleural friction rub suggests pleuritic pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated D-dimer level and the CT findings suggest pulmonary embolism. The physical examination findings that correlate with pulmonary embolism are localized rales, which can occur due to reduced blood flow to the lungs. Bilateral wheezing is seen in asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, systolic murmur at the left sternal border could be due to aortic or pulmonary valve disease, and pleural friction rub is seen in pleuritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated D-dimer and filling defect in a segmental pulmonary artery on the left side suggest pulmonary embolism. Among the options, only localized rales (crackles) are common in pulmonary embolism due to the blockage of blood flow causing inflammation and fluid accumulation in the affected region. Bilateral wheezing and a systolic murmur at the left sternal border are not typical findings in pulmonary embolism. Pleural friction rub is more commonly seen in pleuritis, not pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, history of smoking, and elevated D-dimer level suggest pulmonary embolism. Localized rales, or crackles, are the most likely physical finding observed in patients with pulmonary embolism. Bilateral wheezing is more commonly associated with asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Systolic murmur at the left sternal border is more commonly associated with aortic stenosis or mitral regurgitation. Pleural friction rub is more commonly associated with pleurisy or pneumothorax.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and the elevated D-dimer levels suggest a pulmonary embolism. Localized rales, or crackling sounds heard during breathing, may be observed during physical examination of the chest in a patient with a pulmonary embolism. Bilateral wheezing is more likely to be associated with asthma or bronchitis; a systolic murmur may suggest valvular heart disease; and a pleural friction rub may indicate pleurisy or pneumonia, none of which are specific to pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The details provided suggest pulmonary embolism. Among the physical findings, localized rales are more likely to be heard in pulmonary embolism. Bilateral wheezing could suggest asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, pleural friction rub could suggest pleuritis, and a systolic murmur at the left sternal border could suggest aortic stenosis or mitral regurgitation.
